author: chadpewtin
body: Quick question about this tsla s&p inclusion. Is it typical for a recently added company’s stock to skyrocket after the inclusion or is tsla just a special case ? I was looking at Etsy and teradyne as examples and I guess they kinda went up a lot over a month or two. Wonder if I should be expecting something similar in Tesla’s case.

author: Ka07iiC
body:
I often feel like investing in what you know sets you up to underperform and you are better off buying index funds. Different story if you are older and looking for less risky assets for income.

There are examples where I don't truly understand technically what a business does, but I love the sector, the fundamentals of tbe business, and the reviews of the company from customers and employees. 

Two examples of these in my portfolio are Teradyne and The Trade Desk.

author: kiwimancy
body: The first method. You net short term against short ter and long term against long term, then leftover long/short term against short/long term, then up to 3k additional losses can offset other income and the rest rolls over to next year.

author: Trisolaran_arbitrage
body: Industrial technology and software and robotics - this is where I see a potential for huge growth over the next 10 years. Look at companies like Rockwell Automation, Teradyne, Honeywell, Schneider.

author: theboymehoy
body:
> Im also not a big fan of ETFs because of TER and stuff, so i thought im just going to build my own little ETF with no more than 30 positions.  

unless youi are doing this as your full time job like the people managing etf are, i really don't think you will be better off in the end tbh. isn't some shit like the S&P 500 better than some 85% of pros portfolios?  not saying it should all go in there, but on top of your own portfolio it could be smart to diversify this way

author: BlackOut7722
body:
Im also not a big fan of ETFs because of TER and stuff, so i thought im just going to build my own little ETF with no more than 30 positions. I did however only look for things that are relatively safe and may not have the biggest growth to be expected but increase their dividend steadily, so not much risk to it im afraid if you really are looking for that.



Anyway i got: MMM, ADDYY, KO, HD, MCD, NSRGF, STAG, WMT

Planning on adding: LIN, O, GBERF, WELL, BTI, PG, RHHBY, DEO and way later down the line maybe WM, RIO, UNP.

Also good alternatives i would say: CAT, JNJ/PFE, BRK.B, FDX, AXP

author: kkInkr
body:
By throwing darts. (Anything can happen and please make your decision on your own, not to follow some random guy on internet)

You can try randomly choosing stocks as well. I tried it myself for a year with 37 different ones, and in fact they are far better than professionals'.

Here is what I did, in February 18, I choose these stocks and put $120 into each, FVRR, MRNA, ORTK (previously CATS), TRUP, ZS, VUZI, IIVI, IPHI, VEEV, TER, SLP, ARLO, AAXN, PEGA, SHW, HIMX, CCK, RPM, KEYS, ACN, SWK, MTN, WLFC, SLGN, AMBA, LEN, IMMR, ZUO, ACIA, PSTG, LITE, VIAV, FORR, ISNS, AEP, GILD, D*LY (the letter before L is G, Reddit don't allow me to post)

These have 62% gain so far, and 2 are being added on July 2, which are FORR, and ZUO, and D*LY was sold in July (due to the George Floyd hype at price $3.98, I should have sold at $5 before it died down) and bought again in September.  Out of those 32, LITE, AMBA, VIAV, GILD, ZUO, AEP, ISNS, WLFC are still red, but not much down as before in May or June.

and compare to Tiger Global Management Hedgefunds which I put in money in January 2,  DCA 21% gain (or 1 year return -1.05%) and November 12, 2019 Coatue Management DCA 24% gain (or 1 year return 1.31%)

I beat those professional by a far margin and certainly beat the market, SPY, 7% DCA since Jan 2 (or 1 year return 14%), and QQQ, 9.79% DCA since Jan 30(or 1 year return 43%).

Try it, you may find it more fun than betting.

Best bet for pure play would probably be an etf though.

PocketAces93
body: Seems to be like there’s a clear top tier of CURA, GTII, CL & TRUL followed by a mid tier of TER, CCHW, AYR & HARV. It’ll be interesting to see FFNT, JUSH & VREO’s financials and if any of them can make the jump to the mid tier.

author: Trisolaran_arbitrage
body: I told everyone to buy Teradyne back in September and nobody listened 😟

author: Trisolaran_arbitrage
body: Industrial software- think Honeywell and Schneider. Industrial automation- Teradyne, Rockwell
That's not the reason for the difference. There are distributing hedged share classes of the Core MSCI World ETF with TER 0.30%.
The iShares Core MSCI World ETF has TER 0.2%. I have no idea why they have two ETFs tracking the same index with such different TER figures.

author: pedr0_0
body:
If one person intends to invest 10K to 50K in a Core MSCI World ETF should that person buy:

1)"Lyxor Core MSCI World (DR) UCITS ETF - Acc" with a 0.12% TER https://www.justetf.com/de-en/etf-profile.html?index=MSCI%2BWorld&groupField=none&sortField=ter&sortOrder=asc&from=search&isin=LU1781541179#overview

2) or "iShares Core MSCI World UCITS ETF USD (Acc)" with 0.2% TER https://www.justetf.com/de-en/etf-profile.html?index=MSCI%2BWorld&groupField=none&sortField=ter&sortOrder=asc&from=search&isin=IE00B4L5Y983#overview

iShares has a longer history and a bigger fund, but Lyxor has smaller TER. Does anyone know which should I choose and why?

author: PocketAces93
body: I think that’s a fair assessment. Definitely have some regret on TER as it’s been the biggest gainer since Covid low.

body: One of my biggest regrets is reading people on this sub saying TER was overpriced at $7 and I went with that sentiment. Another reminder to go with YOUR gut, not other people’s. Fuck!

author: MK45124512
body:
I've thought about it - the main benefit being the financing that they provided them for their 'hemp division' (wink wink nod), but realistically, SLNG has a similar relationship and doesnt have much to show for it. There's no real guidance that I'd need CGC to impart on TER, so in my opinion the warrants/ownership can be just looked on the hard financial facts of those warrants themselves.

I guess you could say that it makes them a likely STZ buyout, wouldn't argue with you there, but I feel like most MSOs are buyout targets if we legalize federally.

body: Would suck for TER holders to get dragged through the mud like that

body: What Knowledge said - they're getting a Maryland asset as part of the grassroots transaction that is larger (55k SQFT) than the one they're selling to TER (22k SQFT).

author: gkbuzz
body: Looking for an honest advice here. My portfolio is cannabis heavy. Holding APHA CGC ACB VFF HEXO TER also losers like IAN ISOL WEEDMD TGOD ACREGAE NAMASTE. should I sell before EOD or wait for election results? I am in loss for all of them including CGC APHA VFF. I bought all stocks during legalization hype in 2017/2018. Tried to avg down a bit but didn’t reach break even yet. Holding through election results will be a big gamble for me, so I am very confused if I keep holding or take a loss and rebuild my portfolio when there is less uncertainty? Any honest advice will be appreciated

author: MarchToaMilli
body:
Focus on the leading Multi State Operators (imo):

CURA, CL, GTII, TRUL, TER, CCHW.

MSOS & HMUS are some Multi State Operator focused ETF's that will give you those names & several others.

author: shantmelikian
body:
People were bashing Trul for : SSO, Unlocks... also saying "they will lose market share".

I would argue that they keep on executing and dominating in Florida. Everyone expects them to lose market share but we see quite the opposite. 22% of dispensaries and 52%+ of flower and concentrates week in week out.

If anything, the competition should watch out in other states because they are the only company proven to be number one in sales per store in a state where where there are all the big names (Cura, Gtii, Harv, Medmen, LHS, Surterra...). What will happen when Trul (by surprise) decides to expand in a state where Cresco or Gtii or Cura are present ? They will replicate the winning formula there. I think the competition will lose market share (imo).

Generating the highest fcf is also a reason they continue to expand in the most profitable market. They will be able to use all that $ to fund expansions elsewhere with no/minimal dilution.

All this to say, Trulieve criticisms dont hold up for me personally.

They have opened 23 dispensaries this year alone (organically !!!) with Cura being number 2 with 11 and Gtii number 3 with 10. Can't wait for 2021 additional ~1m sq. ft of cultivation opening until Q12021. 2022 rec in Florida ? 130 million visitors a year also...

P.S. I'm extremely bullish on all top 5 msos (Ter being my number 5). Just commenting my points on why Trul is my #1.
